alert.note: Alert for Morris; Passaic (New Jersey) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 19 at 11:39PM EST until December 20 at 5:00AM EST by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Jersey... Pompton River At Pompton Plains affecting Passaic and Morris Counties. For the Pompton River...including Pompton Plains...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TONIGHT... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Pompton River at Pompton Plains. * WHEN...Until late tonight. * IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, The first flooding begins in the area of River Road and Harrison Street. At 16.0 feet, Residences on Pequannock Avenue along the river between Madison and Shady streets become surrounded by water. Businesses along Route 23 north begin to flood. At 17.0 feet, Pequannock Avenue at Roosevelt Street becomes impassable. Route 23 exit ramp at Alexander Avenue becomes impassable. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:15 PM EST Tuesday the stage was 16.8 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:15 PM EST Tuesday was 21.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late tonight and continue falling to 12.3 feet Friday evening. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.8 feet on 12/12/2003. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Stream Fld Observed Fcsts (1 am) Crest Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Stg Time Date Pompton River Pompton Plains 16.0 16.8 Tue 11 p 13.7 12.9 MSG unknown &&
info.instruction: Turn around...don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/phi. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 500 AM EST.
